channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chad Strongman Says Nigeria Is Absent in Fight Against Boko Haram
item.description: President Idriss Déby of Chad has won favor with the West, which is only too happy to call on his forces in a region seething with Islamist terrorists.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: President Idriss Déby of Chad, right, welcomed his French counterpart, François Hollande, last year in Ndjamena, the capital.

item.title: North Korea Claims to Have Arrested Two Spies From South
item.description: North Korea said on Friday that it had arrested two South Korean men on espionage charges for collecting military and other secrets on the isolated country, including data regarding its top leadership.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Kenya: Official Apology for Past Wrongs
item.description: President Uhuru Kenyatta apologized on Thursday to the Kenyan people for past wrongs committed by his government and previous ones.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: India: 2 Suspects Held in Rape of Nun
item.description: The police arrested two suspects on Thursday in the rape of an elderly nun in a Catholic missionary school this month, a crime that further fueled the intense national debate about the problem of sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: The Prince and the Papers
item.description: The Supreme Court on Thursday paved the way for the public release of 27 memos written by Prince Charles to government ministers.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: An American With Ebola Is Improving
item.description: An American aid worker being treated for Ebola at the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Maryland is doing better and has been upgraded from critical to serious condition, the N.I.H. announced Thursday.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: World Briefing: Ebola Vaccines Pass Initial Safety Tests
item.description: Two experimental Ebola vaccines “appear to be safe” partway through a clinical trial being conducted in Liberia, the National Institutes of Health said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: U.N. Middle East Peace Envoy Urges Security Council to Revive Talks
item.description: Robert Serry, the departing United Nations envoy for the Middle East peace process said that Israel’s policy of building settlements in the Palestinian territories “may kill” any chance of peace.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: U.S. and Syria Discuss Missing Journalist
item.description: The father of Austin Tice, who disappeared in Syria in 2012, and a State Department official said the governments of the two countries had been in direct contact.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: President of Argentina Won’t Face Charges
item.description: The president and her political supporters had been accused of conspiring to hide Iranian officials’ involvement in a bombing Buenos Aires in 1994.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Sudan Joins Coalition Against Yemen Rebels
item.description: The Arab-led, American-supported coalition seeking to rout Houthi rebels in Yemen includes a leader indicted on charges of war crimes and vilified by Washington for more than a decade: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: John F. Burns, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Journalist, Ends Acclaimed Run
item.description: Mr. Burns, who reported from 10 foreign bureaus, has concluded a distinguished career spanning 40 years with The New York Times.
item.media:credit: Lars Klove for The New York Times

item.title: Taking to Twitter, Iran’s President Argues for Rapid End to Sanctions
item.description: On Twitter, Hassan Rouhani described his appeals to President Obama, and the leaders of Britain, France and Russia as nuclear talks near a deadline.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, met Thursday with Secretary of State John Kerry and other officials, including Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz.

item.title: News Analysis: A Policy Puzzle of U.S. Goals and Alliances in the Middle East
item.description: In becoming involved in a Saudi-led campaign to dislodge rebels in Yemen, the United States has created more entanglement with its alliances.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Smoke rising from Tikrit, where the United States and Iran have similar aims. But in Yemen, they are on opposite sides.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac on ‘The China Collectors’
item.description: The authors have written a rollicking account of the acquisition of Chinese art and antiquities by Americans who came to China in the 19th and 20th centuries.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
The China Collectors: America's Century-Long Hunt for Asian Art Treasure (Book)
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Opening New Iraq Front, U.S. Strikes ISIS in Tikrit
item.description: American warplanes began airstrikes against Islamic State positions in the Iraqi city, aiding a three-week offensive by a coalition of Shiite militias and Iraqi security forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and PETER BAKER

item.title: Post-Sept. 11, Cockpits Are Built to Protect From Outside Threats
item.description: By apparently locking the captain out of the cockpit, the co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525 took advantage of a major safety protocol instituted after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD and CHRISTOPHER DREW

item.title: Fatal Descent of Germanwings Plane Was ‘Deliberate,’ French Authorities Say
item.description: The co-pilot initiated the plane’s descent for unknown reasons while he was alone in the cockpit, having locked the pilot out, said the prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Francis Pellier/French Interior Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: French emergency workers at the site of Tuesday’s crash of Germanwings Flight 9525. All 150 people aboard were killed.

item.title: Leicester Journal: Richard III Gets a Kingly Burial, on Second Try
item.description: The archbishop of Canterbury presided over the service on Thursday, but critics said the notorious monarch should not have been given such honors.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury, presided over the reburial ceremony of King Richard III at Leicester Cathedral in England on Thursday.

item.title: Open Source: Yemenis Share Reports, Rumors and Wry Commentary Online as Bombs Drop
item.description: Twitter and Facebook updates and snatches of grainy video on Instagram and YouTube offered observers following from afar vivid glimpses of the terror.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
